title: Quiz 2: NCK Paper One - August 2016
description: Examination for Admission to the Register of Community Health Nurses (Basic) - August 2016. Covers Medical-Surgical, Pharmacology, and Nursing Fundamentals.

questions.question: Obstruction of the hepatopancreatic sphincter impairs digestion by reducing the availability of:
questions.explanation: The hepatopancreatic sphincter (Sphincter of Oddi) controls the flow of both bile (from common bile duct) and pancreatic juice (from pancreatic duct) into the duodenum.
questions.hint: This sphincter is the common exit for the liver/gallbladder and pancreas.

questions.question: Non-specific body defense mechanisms include:
questions.explanation: Non-specific (Innate) immunity includes barriers and cells like Phagocytes and Natural Killer cells. Lymphocytes and antibodies are specific (adaptive) immunity.
questions.hint: Look for components that don't target specific antigens.

questions.question: Mycoses that cause systemic infection include:
questions.explanation: Histoplasmosis and Coccidioidomycosis are systemic fungal infections affecting internal organs. The others are subcutaneous or superficial/cutaneous.
questions.hint: These fungi typically affect the lungs.

questions.question: Patients with COPD are encouraged to exercise because it:
questions.explanation: Exercise training strengthens respiratory muscles and improves oxygen utilization efficiency, reducing dyspnea.
questions.hint: Exercise targets the muscles of breathing.

questions.question: The most appropriate treatment goal for a client with status asthmaticus is:
questions.explanation: Status asthmaticus is a medical emergency. The priority is to reverse obstruction and prevent respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation (intubation).
questions.hint: The goal is to prevent respiratory failure.

questions.question: When caring for a client with emphysema, the oxygen flow rate should not exceed:
questions.explanation: Patients with chronic CO2 retention rely on the hypoxic drive. High oxygen can suppress this drive, causing hypoventilation. Low flow (1-2 L/min) is standard.
questions.hint: Low flow is required to maintain the hypoxic drive.

questions.question: Modified risk factors for cardiovascular disease include:
questions.explanation: Modifiable factors are those that can be changed (Lipids, Blood sugar). Non-modifiable include Age, Gender, Genetics.
questions.hint: Select the option where BOTH factors can be treated or changed.

questions.question: The correct landmark for obtaining apical pulse is left:

options.text: Second intercostal space, mid calvicular line.
Fifth intercostal space, mid axillary line.

questions.explanation: The apex of the heart (PMI) is located at the 5th Intercostal Space, Mid-Clavicular Line.
questions.hint: Think 5th ICS, MCL.

questions.question: A positive Chvostek's sign is a manifestation of:
questions.explanation: Chvostek's sign (facial twitching) indicates neuromuscular irritability caused by low calcium levels.
questions.hint: Associated with tetany and low levels of a specific mineral.

questions.question: The appropriate medication to reverse hypertensive crisis caused by pheochromocytoma is:
questions.explanation: Phentolamine is an alpha-adrenergic blocker used to block the massive catecholamine release in pheochromocytoma.
questions.hint: An alpha-blocker specifically for catecholamine storms.

questions.question: A technique used to assess a patient's peripheral response to pain is:
questions.explanation: Nail bed pressure assesses peripheral pain response. Sternal rub and orbital pressure assess central response.
questions.hint: Peripheral means extremities.

questions.question: Nursing intervention arrived at preventing autonomic dysreflexia includes:
questions.explanation: The most common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia in spinal cord injury is a distended bladder.
questions.hint: Check the catheter.

questions.question: The pathogenesis of compartment syndrome involves:

options.text: Injury to the nerve supply in the affected area.
Fascia expanding in the affected area.
Bleeding and edema increasing pressure in the affected area.
Impaired perfusion in the affected area due to arterial damage.

questions.explanation: Increased pressure from bleeding/edema within a confined fascial space compresses vessels and nerves. Fascia does NOT expand.
questions.hint: Increased pressure within a closed space.

questions.question: A laboratory diagnosis that primarily indicates pancreatitis is:
questions.explanation: Serum Lipase is specific to the pancreas and remains elevated longer than Amylase.
questions.hint: Lipase breaks down lipids/fats.

questions.question: A contra-indication to ear irrigation is:
questions.explanation: Irrigating a perforated eardrum can force bacteria into the middle ear, causing severe infection.
questions.hint: Do not put fluid where the barrier is broken.

questions.question: The appropriate fluid to administer during emergency fluid resuscitation in burns is:
questions.explanation: Isotonic crystalloids (like Ringer's Lactate) are standard for initial burn resuscitation to replace lost fluids and electrolytes.
questions.hint: Think Parkland formula.

questions.question: The first action to take when you find an unconscious victim is:
questions.explanation: Always ensure the scene is safe before approaching a victim to prevent becoming a victim yourself.
questions.hint: Danger, Response, Airway...

questions.question: The appropriate drug to administer in acute narrow angle glaucoma is:
questions.explanation: Acetazolamide decreases aqueous humor production. Atropine is contraindicated as it dilates the pupil, worsening the block.
questions.hint: A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

questions.question: The appropriate health message for a client treated to chronic renal failure is:
questions.explanation: Carbs provide energy and spare protein. Protein, Potassium (bananas), Salt, and Fluids are typically restricted.
questions.hint: Protein sparing.

questions.question: A diagnostic test for hemophilia is:
questions.explanation: Hemophilia affects the intrinsic pathway (Factor VIII/IX), prolonging the PTT. Bleeding time assesses platelets.
questions.hint: Intrinsic pathway test.

questions.question: Select the correct characteristics of Carbamazepine:

options.text: Blocks sodium channels to stabilize nerve membranes.
Indicated for Epilepsy and Trigeminal Neuralgia.

questions.explanation: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant that blocks sodium channels. It treats epilepsy and trigeminal neuralgia but has bone marrow suppression risks.
questions.hint: Anticonvulsant drug.

questions.question: Which nursing interventions are appropriate for a client with Osteomyelitis?

options.text: Encourage vigorous exercise of the limb.
Handle the limb roughly to test pain.

questions.explanation: Immobilization prevents fracture; antibiotics treat infection; protein aids healing. Movement should be gentle.
questions.hint: Bone infection requires rest and nutrition.

questions.question: Select appropriate interventions for Increased Intracranial Pressure (ICP):
questions.explanation: Elevation promotes drainage. Mannitol draws fluid out. Quiet and fever control reduce metabolic demand. Straining increases ICP.
questions.hint: Interventions focus on reducing brain volume and pressure.

questions.question: Arrange the steps in the pathophysiology of Acne Vulgaris:

items.text: Dead skin cells clog the pore (comedone)
Bacteria (P. acnes) proliferate in the pore

questions.explanation: Sebum -> Clog -> Bacteria -> Inflammation.
questions.hint: It starts with hormones and oil.

questions.question: Which interventions are indicated for Pulmonary Edema?

options.text: High Fowler's position with legs dangling.

questions.explanation: Upright position reduces venous return. Diuretics remove fluid. Oxygen treats hypoxia.
questions.hint: MAD DOG: Morphine, Aminophylline, Digitalis, Diuretics, Oxygen, Gases (Position).

questions.question: What are clinical manifestations of Dumping Syndrome?
questions.explanation: Rapid emptying leads to fluid shift (hypovolemia symptoms like tachycardia/dizziness) and bowel irritation (cramps/diarrhea).
questions.hint: Symptoms occur shortly after eating.

questions.question: Select the appropriate discharge advice for a patient with Renal Stones:

options.text: Modify diet based on stone type.

questions.explanation: Fluids flush the system. Activity prevents stasis. Diet prevents formation.
questions.hint: Hydration is key.

questions.question: Mr. K has Arrhythmia. Select the correct types and interventions:
questions.explanation: Arrhythmias include AF, VT, VF. Monitoring and meds are standard care.
questions.hint: Identify abnormal rhythms and safety checks.

questions.question: Case Study: Mr. X is undergoing Total Hip Replacement. Which care steps are correct?

richContent.content:
Case: Total Hip Replacement

Mr. X is post-op day 1. Focus on positioning and prevention of complications.

options.text: Maintain abduction of legs using a wedge pillow.
Allow patient to cross legs for comfort.
Monitor neurovascular status of the limb.

questions.explanation: Abduction and avoiding flexion >90 degrees prevent dislocation. Crossing legs is forbidden.
questions.hint: Prevent dislocation of the prosthesis.

questions.question: Match the feature to either DKA or HNKS:

richContent.content:
Hyperglycemic Emergencies

Differentiate between Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) and Hyperosmolar Non-Ketotic Syndrome (HNKS).

questions.explanation: DKA involves acidosis and ketones (Type 1). HNKS involves extreme hyperglycemia without ketones (Type 2).
questions.hint: Ketoacidosis is in the name DKA.
